results:
Based on my search results, I can provide you with information about the 1968 film "Lalka" (The Doll) directed by Wojciech Has:

## Critical Reception

The film received mixed to positive reviews from critics and audiences:

- The film has a 6.9 rating on IMDB
- It was rated the #83 best film of 1968, and #4514 in the greatest all-time movies (according to RYM users)
- One reviewer gave it ★★★½, praising the "Beautifully composed long shots that take us through environments that are constantly reminding us about the social strata"

Critics particularly praised Wojciech Has's visual style:
- "Wojciech Has is probably one of the most mesmerizing directors ever. He's one of these rare directors who manage to make the viewers forget their accounts just by depicting the most beautiful scenes"
- The shots were described as "full of incredible details which are reminiscent of gothic art and surrealism"

However, some critics found the adaptation lacking compared to the source material:
- One Polish review stated: "Jeśli ktoś po przeczytaniu powieści Prusa wciąż wątpi w to, że jest ona arcydziełem, powinien obejrzeć film Hasa. Dopiero wtedy zobaczy, że żaden film nie będzie w stanie unieść tego, co niesie ze sobą 'Lalka'" (suggesting the film couldn't match the novel's depth)
- Another reviewer felt "the characters, especially Wokulski, were just... shallow"
- "it is somewhat forgettable and overshadowed by his many masterpieces. So far, this is my least favorite has film"

## Box Office Earnings

Unfortunately, I could not find any specific box office earnings or financial performance data for "Lalka" (1968) in the search results. The film appears to have been primarily a domestic Polish release, and box office records from that era for Polish films are not readily available in the search results.

The film is an adaptation of the novel The Doll by Bolesław Prus, which "is regarded by many as one of the finest Polish novels ever written". The story is "a subtle story of three generations of Polish idealists, their psychological complications, their involvement in the history of the nineteenth century, social dramas, moral problems and the experience of tragic existence".
